Good-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK SECOND. LITTLE AGGIE\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham stopped on the threshold with the sharp surprise of the\r\nsight of her son, and there was disappointment, though rather of the\r\nafflicted than of the irritated sort, in the question that, slowly\r\nadvancing, she launched at him. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re still lolling about why did\r\nyou tell me two hours ago that you were leaving immediately?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDeep in a large brocaded chair with his little legs stuck out to the\r\nfire, he was so much at his ease that he was almost flat on his back.\r\nShe had evidently roused him from sleep, and it took him a couple\r\nof minutes--during which, without again looking at him, she directly\r\napproached a beautiful old French secretary, a fine piece of the period\r\nof Louis Seize--to justify his presence. \xe2\x80\x9cI changed my mind. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nget off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to say you\xe2\x80\x99re not going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m thinking it over. What\xe2\x80\x99s a fellow to do?\xe2\x80\x9d He sat up a little,\r\nstaring with conscious solemnity at the fire, and if it had been--as\r\nit was not--one of the annoyances she in general expected from him,\r\nshe might have received the impression that his flush was the heat of\r\nliquor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s to keep out of the way,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned--\xe2\x80\x9cwhen he has led one so\r\ndeeply to hope it.\xe2\x80\x9d There had been a bunch of keys dangling from\r\nthe secretary, of which as she said these words Mrs. Brookenham took\r\npossession. Her air on observing them had promptly become that of having\r\nbeen in search of them, and a moment after she had passed across the\r\nroom they were in her pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t go what excuse will you\r\ngive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to YOU, mummy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stood before him and now dismally looked at him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter\r\nwith you? What an extraordinary time to take a nap!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had fallen back in the chair, from the depths of which he met her\r\neyes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy it\xe2\x80\x99s just THE time, mummy. I did it on purpose. I can always\r\ngo to sleep when I like. I assure you it sees one through things!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe turned away with impatience and, glancing about the room, perceived\r\non a small table of the same type as the secretary a somewhat massive\r\nbook with the label of a circulating library, which she proceeded to\r\npick up as for refuge from the impression made on her by her boy. He\r\nwatched her do this and watched her then slightly pause at the wide\r\nwindow that, in Buckingham Crescent, commanded the prospect they had\r\nramified rearward to enjoy; a medley of smoky brick and spotty stucco,\r\nof other undressed backs, of glass invidiously opaque, of roofs and\r\nchimney-pots and stables unnaturally near--one of the private pictures\r\nthat in London, in select situations, run up, as the phrase is, the\r\nrent. There was no indication of value now, however, in the character\r\nconferred on the scene by a cold spring rain. The place had moreover\r\na confessed out-of-season vacancy. She appeared to have determined on\r\nsilence for the present mark of her relation with Harold, yet she soon\r\nfailed to resist a sufficiently poor reason for breaking it. \xe2\x80\x9cBe so good\r\nas to get out of my chair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will you do for me,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cif I oblige you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe never moved--but as if only the more directly and intimately to meet\r\nher--and she stood again before the fire and sounded his strange little\r\nface. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it is, but you give me sometimes a kind of\r\nterror.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA terror, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe found another place, sinking sadly down and opening her book, and\r\nthe next moment he got up and came over to kiss her, on which she drew\r\nher cheek wearily aside. \xe2\x80\x9cYou bore me quite to death,\xe2\x80\x9d she coldly said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand I give you up to your fate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you call my fate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh something dreadful--if only by its being publicly ridiculous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n She turned vaguely the pages of her book. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re too selfish--too\r\nsickening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d he wonderingly whistled while he wandered back to the\r\nhearth-rug, on which, with his hands behind him, he lingered a while.\r\nHe was small and had a slight stoop which somehow gave him\r\ncharacter--character of the insidious sort carried out in the acuteness,\r\ndifficult to trace to a source, of his smooth fair face, where the lines\r\nwere all curves and the expression all needles. He had the voice of a\r\nman of forty and was dressed--as if markedly not for London--with an\r\nair of experience that seemed to match it. He pulled down his waistcoat,\r\nsmoothing himself, feeling his neat hair and looking at his shoes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI took your five pounds. Also two of the sovereigns,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nleft you two pound ten.\xe2\x80\x9d His mother jerked up her head at this,\r\nfacing him in dismay, and, immediately on her feet, passed back to the\r\nsecretary. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s quite as I say,\xe2\x80\x9d he insisted; \xe2\x80\x9cyou should have locked\r\nit BEFORE, don\xe2\x80\x99t you know? It grinned at me there with all its charming\r\nbrasses, and what was I to do? Darling mummy, I COULDN\xe2\x80\x99T start--that was\r\nthe truth. I thought I should find something--I had noticed; and I do\r\nhope you\xe2\x80\x99ll let me keep it, because if you don\xe2\x80\x99t it\xe2\x80\x99s all up with me. I\r\nstopped over on purpose--on purpose, I mean, to tell you what I\xe2\x80\x99ve done.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t you call that a sense of honour? And now you only stand and glower\r\nat me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham was, in her forty-first year, still charmingly pretty,\r\nand the nearest approach she made at this moment to meeting her son\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndescription of her was by looking beautifully desperate. She had about\r\nher the pure light of youth--would always have it; her head, her figure,\r\nher flexibility, her flickering colour, her lovely silly eyes, her\r\nnatural quavering tone, all played together toward this effect by\r\nsome trick that had never yet been exposed. It was at the same time\r\nremarkable that--at least in the bosom of her family--she rarely wore\r\nan appearance of gaiety less qualified than at the present juncture;\r\nshe suggested for the most part the luxury, the novelty of woe, the\r\nexcitement of strange sorrows and the cultivation of fine indifferences.\r\nThis was her special sign--an innocence dimly tragic. It gave immense\r\neffect to her other resources. She opened the secretary with the key\r\nshe had quickly found, then with the aid of another rattled out a small\r\ndrawer; after which she pushed the drawer back, closing the whole thing.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou terrify me--you terrify me,\xe2\x80\x9d she again said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you say that when you showed me just now how well you know me?\r\nWasn\xe2\x80\x99t it just on account of what you thought I might do that you took\r\nout the keys as soon as you came in?\xe2\x80\x9d Harold\xe2\x80\x99s manner had a way of\r\nclearing up whenever he could talk of himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re too utterly disgusting--I shall speak to your father,\xe2\x80\x9d with\r\nwhich, going to the chair he had given up, his mother sank down again\r\nwith her heavy book. There was no anger, however, in her voice, and\r\nnot even a harsh plaint; only a detached accepted disenchantment. Mrs.\r\nBrookenham\xe2\x80\x99s supreme rebellion against fate was just to show with the\r\nlast frankness how much she was bored.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, darling mummy, you won\xe2\x80\x99t speak to my father--you\xe2\x80\x99ll do anything in\r\nthe world rather than that,\xe2\x80\x9d Harold replied, quite as if he were kindly\r\nexplaining her to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cI thank you immensely for the charming way\r\nyou take what I\xe2\x80\x99ve done; it was because I had a conviction of that that\r\nI waited for you to know it. It was all very well to tell you I\xe2\x80\x99d start\r\non my visit--but how the deuce was I to start without a penny in the\r\nworld? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see that if you want me to go about you must really\r\nenter into my needs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to heaven you\xe2\x80\x99d leave me--I wish to heaven you\xe2\x80\x99d get out of the\r\nhouse,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brookenham went on without looking up.\r\n\r\nHarold took out his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, mamma, now I AM ready: I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in\r\nthe least before. But it will be going forth, you know, quite to seek\r\nmy fortune. For do you really think--I must have from you what you do\r\nthink--that it will be all right for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe fixed him at last with her pretty pathos. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mean for you to go to\r\nBrander?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered with his manner as of letting her see her own\r\nattitude, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know you try to make me do things you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t at all do\r\nyourself. At least I hope you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. And don\xe2\x80\x99t you see that if I so\r\nfar oblige you I must at least be paid for it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis mother leaned back in her chair, gazed for a moment at the ceiling\r\nand then closed her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cYou ARE frightful,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nappalling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always wanting to get me out of the house,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthink you want to get us ALL out, for you manage to keep Nanda from\r\nshowing even more than you do me. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think your children good\r\nENOUGH, mummy dear? At any rate it\xe2\x80\x99s as plain as possible that if you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t keep us at home you must keep us in other places. One can\xe2\x80\x99t live\r\nanywhere for nothing--it\xe2\x80\x99s all bosh that a fellow saves by staying with\r\npeople. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how it is for a lady, but a man\xe2\x80\x99s practically let\r\nin--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know you kill me, Harold?\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brookenham woefully interposed.\r\nBut it was with the same remote melancholy that she asked in the next\r\nbreath: \xe2\x80\x9cIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t an INVITATION--to Brander?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s as I told you. She said she\xe2\x80\x99d write, fixing a time; but she never\r\ndid write.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if YOU wrote--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt comes to the same thing? DOES it?--that\xe2\x80\x99s the question. If on my\r\nnote she didn\xe2\x80\x99t write--that\xe2\x80\x99s what I mean. Should one simply take it\r\nthat one\xe2\x80\x99s wanted? I like to have these things FROM you, mother. I do, I\r\nbelieve, everything you say; but to feel safe and right I must just HAVE\r\nthem. Any one WOULD want me, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham had opened her eyes, but she still attached them to the\r\ncornice. \xe2\x80\x9cIf she hadn\xe2\x80\x99t wanted you she\xe2\x80\x99d have written to keep you off.\r\nIn a great house like that there\xe2\x80\x99s always room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man watched her a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cHow you DO like to tuck us in and\r\nthen sit up yourself! What do you want to do, anyway? What ARE you up\r\nto, mummy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe rose at this, turning her eyes about the room as if from the\r\nextremity of martyrdom or the wistfulness of some deep thought. Yet when\r\nshe spoke it was with a different expression, an expression that\r\nwould have served for an observer as a marked illustration of that\r\ndisconnectedness of her parts which frequently was laughable even to the\r\ndegree of contributing to her social success. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve spent then more\r\nthan four pounds in five days. It was on Friday I gave them to you. What\r\nin the world do you suppose is going to become of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHarold continued to look at her as if the question demanded some answer\r\nreally helpful. \xe2\x80\x9cDo we live beyond our means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe now moved her gaze to the floor. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you PLEASE get away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnything to assist you. Only, if I SHOULD find I\xe2\x80\x99m not wanted--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe met his look after an instant, and the wan loveliness and vagueness\r\nof her own had never been greater. \xe2\x80\x9cBE wanted, and you won\xe2\x80\x99t find it.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re odious, but you\xe2\x80\x99re not a fool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe put his arms about her now for farewell, and she submitted as if it\r\nwas absolutely indifferent to her to whose bosom she was pressed. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\ndo, dearest,\xe2\x80\x9d he laughed, \xe2\x80\x9csay such sweet things!\xe2\x80\x9d And with that he\r\nreached the door, on opening which he pulled up at a sound from below.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Duchess! She\xe2\x80\x99s coming up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham looked quickly round the room, but she spoke with utter\r\ndetachment. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, let her come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I\xe2\x80\x99d let her go. I take it as a happy sign SHE won\xe2\x80\x99t be at Brander.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n He stood with his hand on the knob; he had another quick appeal. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\r\nafter Tuesday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham had passed half round the room with the glide that\r\nlooked languid but that was really a remarkable form of activity, and\r\nhad given a transforming touch, on sofa and chairs, to three or four\r\ncrushed cushions. It was all with the hanging head of a broken lily.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re to stay till the twelfth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if I AM kicked out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was as a broken lily that she considered it. \xe2\x80\x9cThen go to the\r\nMangers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappy thought! And shall I write?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis mother raised a little more a window-blind. \xe2\x80\x9cNo--I will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDelicious mummy!\xe2\x80\x9d And Harold blew her a kiss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, rather\xe2\x80\x9d--she corrected herself. \xe2\x80\x9cDo write--from Brander. It\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nsort of thing for the Mangers. Or even wire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoth?\xe2\x80\x9d the young man laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cOh you duck!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd from where\r\nwill YOU let them have it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Pewbury,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied without wincing. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll write on Sunday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood. How d\xe2\x80\x99ye do, Duchess?\xe2\x80\x9d--and Harold, before he disappeared,\r\ngreeted with a rapid concentration of all the shades of familiarity a\r\nlarge high lady, the visitor he had announced, who rose in the doorway\r\nwith the manner of a person used to arriving on thresholds very much as\r\npeople arrive at stations--with the expectation of being \xe2\x80\x9cmet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nII\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye. He\xe2\x80\x99s off,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brookenham, who had remained quite on her own\r\nside of the room, explained to her friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s he off to?\xe2\x80\x9d this friend enquired with a casual advance and a\r\nlook not so much at her hostess as at the cushions just rearranged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh to some places. To Brander to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow he does run about!\xe2\x80\x9d And the Duchess, still with a glance hither\r\nand yon, sank upon the sofa to which she had made her way unaided. Mrs.\r\nBrookenham knew perfectly the meaning of this glance: she had but three\r\nor four comparatively good pieces, whereas the Duchess, rich with the\r\nspoils of Italy, had but three or four comparatively bad. This was\r\nthe relation, as between intimate friends, that the Duchess visibly\r\npreferred, and it was quite groundless, in Buckingham Crescent, ever to\r\nenter the drawing-room with an expression suspicious of disloyalty. The\r\nDuchess was a woman who so cultivated her passions that she would have\r\nregarded it as disloyal to introduce there a new piece of furniture in\r\nan underhand way--that is without a full appeal to herself, the highest\r\nauthority, and the consequent bestowal of opportunity to nip the mistake\r\nin the bud. Mrs. Brookenham had repeatedly asked herself where in the\r\nworld she might have found the money to be disloyal. The Duchess\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nstandard was of a height--! It matched for that matter her other\r\nelements, which were wontedly conspicuous as usual as she sat there\r\nsuggestive of early tea. She always suggested tea before the hour, and\r\nher friend always, but with so different a wistfulness, rang for it.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s to be at Brander?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t the least idea--he didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell me. But they\xe2\x80\x99ve always a lot\r\nof people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh I know--extraordinary mixtures. Has he been there before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham thought. \xe2\x80\x9cOh yes--if I remember--more than once. In\r\nfact her note--which he showed me, but which only mentioned \xe2\x80\x98some\r\nfriends\xe2\x80\x99--was a sort of appeal on the ground of something or other that\r\nhad happened the last time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Duchess dealt with it. \xe2\x80\x9cShe writes the most extraordinary notes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this was nice, I thought,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brookenham said--\xe2\x80\x9cfrom a woman of\r\nher age and her immense position to so young a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain the Duchess reflected. \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear, she\xe2\x80\x99s not an American and she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot on the stage. Aren\xe2\x80\x99t those what you call positions in this country?\r\nAnd she\xe2\x80\x99s also not a hundred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but Harold\xe2\x80\x99s a mere baby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to want for nurses!\xe2\x80\x9d the Duchess replied. She\r\nsmiled at her hostess. \xe2\x80\x9cYour children are like their mother--they\xe2\x80\x99re\r\neternally young.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99M not a hundred!\xe2\x80\x9d moaned Mrs. Brookenham as if she wished with\r\ndim perversity she were.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery one\xe2\x80\x99s at any rate awfully kind to Harold.\xe2\x80\x9d She waited a moment to\r\ngive her visitor the chance to pronounce that eminently natural, but no\r\npronouncement came--nothing but the footman who had answered her ring\r\nand of whom she ordered tea. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd where did you say YOU\xe2\x80\x99RE going?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nenquired after this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor Easter?\xe2\x80\x9d The Duchess achieved a direct encounter with her charming\r\neyes--which was not in general an easy feat. \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t say I was going\r\nanywhere. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t of a sudden changed my habits. You know whether I\r\nleave my child--except in the sense of having left her an hour ago at\r\nMr. Garlick\xe2\x80\x99s class in Modern Light Literature. I confess I\xe2\x80\x99m a little\r\nnervous about the subjects and am going for her at five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then where do you take her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHome to her tea. Where should you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham declined, in connexion with the matter, any\r\nresponsibility of thought; she did indeed much better by saying after a\r\nmoment: \xe2\x80\x9cYou ARE devoted!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Merriman has her afternoon--I can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine what they do with\r\ntheir afternoons,\xe2\x80\x9d the Duchess went on. \xe2\x80\x9cBut she\xe2\x80\x99s to be back in the\r\nschool-room at seven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have Aggie till then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Duchess cheerfully. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re off for Easter\r\nto--where is it?\xe2\x80\x9d she continued.\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham had received with no flush of betrayal the various\r\ndiscriminations thus conveyed by her visitor, and her only revenge for\r\nthe moment was to look as sweetly resigned as if she really saw what was\r\nin them. Where were they going for Easter? She had to think an instant,\r\nbut she brought it out. \xe2\x80\x9cOh to Pewbury--we\xe2\x80\x99ve been engaged so long that\r\nI had forgotten. Then why are you poor things asked?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham looked, on this, quite adorably--that is most\r\nwonderingly--grave. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do I know, my dear Jane, why in the world we\xe2\x80\x99re\r\never asked anywhere? She was a person of no small presence, filling\r\nher place, however, without ponderosity, with a massiveness indeed\r\nrather artfully kept in bounds. Her head, her chin, her shoulders were\r\nwell aloft, but she had not abandoned the cultivation of a \xe2\x80\x9cfigure\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\nany of the distinctively finer reasons for passing as a handsome woman.\r\nShe was secretly at war moreover, in this endeavour, with a lurking no\r\nless than with a public foe, and thoroughly aware that if she didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlook well she might at times only, and quite dreadfully, look good.\r\nThere were definite ways of escape, none of which she neglected and from\r\nthe total of which, as she flattered herself, the air of distinction\r\nalmost mathematically resulted. The battle-ground then was the\r\nhaunting danger of the bourgeois. He had a pale cold face, marked and made regular, made\r\neven in a manner handsome, by a hardness of line in which, oddly,\r\nthere was no significance, no accent. Clean-shaven, slightly bald, with\r\nunlighted grey eyes and a mouth that gave the impression of not working\r\neasily, he suggested a stippled drawing by an inferior master. Lean\r\nmoreover and stiff, and with the air of having here and there in his\r\nperson a bone or two more than his share, he had once or twice, at\r\nfancy-balls, been thought striking in a dress copied from one of\r\nHolbein\xe2\x80\x99s English portraits. If anything particular had finally been expected from him it\r\nmight have been a summary or an explanation of the things he had always\r\nnot said; but there was something in him that had long since pacified\r\nall impatience, drugged all curiosity. He had never in his life answered\r\nsuch a question as his wife had just put him and which she would\r\nnot have put had she feared a reply. I am now,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brookenham, with\r\na fine emphasis on her adverb, proclaimed as she turned to meet\r\nthe opening of the door and the appearance of the butler, whose\r\nannouncement--\xe2\x80\x9cLord Petherton and Mr. Mitchett\xe2\x80\x9d--might for an observer\r\nhave seemed immediately to offer support to her changed state.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIV\r\n\r\nLord Petherton, a man of five-and-thirty, whose robust but symmetrical\r\nproportions gave to his dark blue double-breasted coat an air of\r\ntightness that just failed of compromising his tailor, had for his main\r\nfacial sign a certain pleasant brutality, the effect partly of a bold\r\nhandsome parade of carnivorous teeth, partly of an expression of nose\r\nsuggesting that this feature had paid a little, in the heat of youth,\r\nfor some aggression at the time admired and even publicly commemorated.\r\nHe would have been ugly, he substantively granted, had he not been\r\nhappy; he would have been dangerous had he not been warranted. Many\r\nthings doubtless performed for him this last service, but none so much\r\nas the delightful sound of his voice, the voice, as it were, of another\r\nman, a nature reclaimed, supercivilised, adjusted to the perpetual\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cchaff\xe2\x80\x9d which kept him smiling in a way that would have been a mistake\r\nand indeed an impossibility if he had really been witty. His bright\r\nfamiliarity was that of a young prince whose confidence had never had to\r\nfalter, and the only thing that at all qualified the resemblance was the\r\nequal familiarity excited in his subjects.\r\n\r\nMr. Mitchett had so little intrinsic appearance that an observer would\r\nhave felt indebted for help in placing him to the rare prominence of\r\nhis colourless eyes and the positive attention drawn to his chin by the\r\nprecipitation of its retreat from discovery. Dressed on the other hand\r\nnot as gentlemen dress in London to pay their respects to the fair, he\r\nexcited by the exhibition of garments that had nothing in common save\r\nthe violence and the independence of their pattern a belief that in the\r\ndesperation of humility he wished to render public his having thrown to\r\nthe winds the effort to please. It was written all over him that he\r\nhad judged once for all his personal case and that, as his character,\r\nsuperficially disposed to gaiety, deprived him of the resource of\r\nshyness and shade, the effect of comedy might not escape him if secured\r\nby a real plunge. There was comedy therefore in the form of his pot-hat\r\nand the colour of his spotted shirt, in the systematic disagreement,\r\nabove all, of his coat, waistcoat and trousers. It was only on long\r\nacquaintance that his so many ingenious ways of showing he appreciated\r\nhis commonness could present him as secretly rare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where\xe2\x80\x99s the child this time?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of his hostess as soon as he\r\nwas seated near her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you say \xe2\x80\x98this time\xe2\x80\x99 as if it were different from any other\r\ntime?\xe2\x80\x9d she replied as she gave him his tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly because, as the months and the years elapse, it\xe2\x80\x99s more and more\r\nof a wonder, whenever I don\xe2\x80\x99t see her, to think what she does with\r\nherself--or what you do with her. Most other people\r\nare sticking fast in their native mud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMud, Mrs. Brook--mud, mud!\xe2\x80\x9d he protestingly cried as, while he watched\r\nhis fellow visitor move to a distance with their host, he glanced about\r\nthe room, taking in afresh the Louis Seize secretary which looked better\r\nclosed than open and for which he always had a knowing eye. \xe2\x80\x9cRemarkably\r\ncharming--mud!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s what a great deal of the element really appears to-day to\r\nbe thought; and precisely as a specimen, Mitchy dear, those two French\r\nbooks you were so good as to send me and which--really this time, you\r\nextraordinary man!\xe2\x80\x9d She fell back, intimately reproachful, from the\r\neffect produced on her, renouncing all expression save that of the\r\nrolled eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, were they particularly dreadful?\xe2\x80\x9d--Mitchy was honestly surprised.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI rather liked the one in the pink cover--what\xe2\x80\x99s the confounded thing\r\ncalled?--I thought it had a sort of a something-or-other.\xe2\x80\x9d He had cast\r\nhis eye about as if for a glimpse of the forgotten title, and she caught\r\nthe question as he vaguely and good-humouredly dropped it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA kind of a morbid modernity? YOU\r\nstay with me--we have our affair.\xe2\x80\x9d The latter of these commands the\r\nDuchess addressed to Mr. Mitchett, while their companion, in obedience\r\nto the former and affected, as it seemed, by an unrepressed familiar\r\naccent that stirred a fresh flicker of Mitchy\xe2\x80\x99s grin, met the new\r\narrival in the middle of the room before Mrs. Brookenham had had time\r\nto reach her. But see,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he immediately added, \xe2\x80\x9chow perfectly competent to instruct her our\r\nfriend now looks.\xe2\x80\x9d Their hostess had advanced to Lady Fanny with an\r\noutstretched hand but with an eagerness of greeting merged a little\r\nin the sweet predominance of wonder as well as in the habit, at such\r\nmoments most perceptible, of the languid lily-bend. Nothing in general\r\ncould have been less conventionally poor than the kind of reception\r\ngiven in Mrs. Brookenham\xe2\x80\x99s drawing-room to the particular element--the\r\nelement of physical splendour void of those disparities that make the\r\nquestion of others tiresome--comprised in Lady Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s presence. It\r\nwas a place in which, at all times, before interesting objects, the\r\nunanimous occupants, almost more concerned for each other\xe2\x80\x99s vibrations\r\nthan for anything else, were apt rather more to exchange sharp and\r\nsilent searchings than to fix their eyes on the object itself. In the\r\ncase of Lady Fanny, however, the object itself--and quite by the same\r\nlaw that had worked, though less profoundly, on the entrance of little\r\nAggie--superseded the usual rapt communion very much in the manner of\r\nsome beautiful tame tigress who might really coerce attention. There\r\nwas in Mrs. Brookenham\xe2\x80\x99s way of looking up at her a dim despairing\r\nabandonment of the idea of any common personal ground. Lady Fanny,\r\nmagnificent, simple, stupid, had almost the stature of her brother,\r\na forehead unsurpassably low and an air of sombre concentration just\r\nsufficiently corrected by something in her movements that failed to give\r\nit a point. It was poor Mrs. Donner--not, like Mrs. Brook, subtle in\r\nsufficiency, nor, like Lady Fanny, almost too simple--who made the\r\npoorest show. LONGDON\r\n\r\nIf Mitchy arrived exactly at the hour it was quite by design and on a\r\ncalculation--over and above the prized little pleasure it might give\r\nhim--of ten minutes clear with his host, whom it rarely befell him to\r\nsee alone. He had a theory of something special to go into, of a\r\nplummet to sink or a feeler to put forth; his state of mind in short\r\nwas diplomatic and anxious. But his hopes had a drop as he crossed\r\nthe threshold. His precaution had only assured him the company of a\r\nstranger, for the person in the room to whom the servant announced\r\nhim was not old Van. But he won\xe2\x80\x99t treat her to comedy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIII\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it the shock of the resemblance to her grandmother?\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank had\r\nasked of Mr. Longdon on rejoining him in his retreat. CASHMORE\r\n\r\nHarold Brookenham, whom Mr. Cashmore, ushered in and announced, had\r\nfound in the act of helping himself to a cup of tea at the table\r\napparently just prepared--Harold Brookenham arrived at the point with\r\na dash so direct as to leave the visitor an option between but two\r\nsuppositions: that of a desperate plunge, to have his shame soon over,\r\nor that of the acquired habit of such appeals, which had taught him the\r\neasiest way. There was no great sharpness in the face of Mr. Cashmore,\r\nwho was somehow massive without majesty; yet he mightn\xe2\x80\x99t have been proof\r\nagainst the suspicion that his young friend\xe2\x80\x99s embarrassment was an\r\neasy precaution, a conscious corrective to the danger of audacity. It\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been impossible to divine that if Harold shut his eyes and\r\njumped it was mainly for the appearance of doing so. Experience was to\r\nbe taken as showing that one might get a five-pound note as one got a\r\nlight for a cigarette; but one had to check the friendly impulse to ask\r\nfor it in the same way. Mr. Cashmore had in fact looked surprised, yet\r\nnot on the whole so surprised as the young man seemed to have expected\r\nof him. I say, Mrs. Brook!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Cashmore flourished on.\r\n\r\nIt was only now that she noticed him; which she did indeed but by\r\nanswering Vanderbank. \xe2\x80\x9cShe didn\xe2\x80\x99t go for YOU I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid--though of\r\ncourse she might: she went because you had promised her Mr. Longdon. May you never have less to brag of!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish she\xe2\x80\x99d bring ME a pound of tea!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Cashmore resumed. \xe2\x80\x9cOr ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nI enough of an old woman for her to come and read to me at home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes she habitually visit the workhouse?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Longdon enquired of Mrs.\r\nBrook.\r\n\r\nThis lady kept him in a moment\xe2\x80\x99s suspense, which another contemplation\r\nmight moreover have detected that Vanderbank in some degree shared.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery Friday at three.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank, with a sudden turn, moved straight to one of the windows,\r\nand Mr. Cashmore had a happy remembrance. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this is Friday--she must\r\nhave gone to-day. The question of--well, what do you call it?--their\r\nexposure. It\xe2\x80\x99s THE question, it appears--the question--of the future;\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s awfully interesting and the Duchess at any rate is great on it.\r\nNanda of course is exposed,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brook pursued--\xe2\x80\x9cfearfully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what on earth is she exposed to?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Cashmore gaily demanded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s exposed to YOU, it would seem, my dear fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank\r\nspoke with a certain discernible impatience not so much of the fact he\r\nmentioned as of the turn of their talk.\r\n\r\nIt might have been in almost compassionate deprecation of this weak\r\nnote that Mrs. Brookenham looked at him. She IS in a boat--but she\xe2\x80\x99s an\r\nexperienced mariner. Basta, as she would say. Do you know Mitchy?\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs.\r\nBrook suddenly asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, he knows Mitchy\xe2\x80\x9d--Vanderbank had approached again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen make HIM tell him\xe2\x80\x9d--she put it before the young man as a charming\r\nturn for them all. \xe2\x80\x9cMitchy CAN be refined when he tries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear--when Mitchy \xe2\x80\x98tries\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cI think I should\r\nrather, for the job, offer him to Mr. Longdon abandoned to his native\r\nwild impulse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI LIKE Mr. Mitchett,\xe2\x80\x9d the old man said, endeavouring to look his\r\nhostess straight in the eye and speaking as if somewhat to defy her to\r\nconvict him, even from the point of view of Beccles, of a mistake.\r\n\r\nMrs. Brookenham took it with a wonderful bright emotion. \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear\r\nfriend, vous me rendez la vie! But\r\nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t we a hope of Nanda?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt might be of use for us to wait for her?\xe2\x80\x9d--it was still to his young\r\nfriend that Mr. Longdon put it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh when she\xe2\x80\x99s once on the loose--!\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brookenham sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnless la voila,\xe2\x80\x9d she said as a hand was heard at the door-latch. It\r\nwas only, however, a footman who entered with a little tray that, on\r\nhis approaching his mistress, offered to sight the brown envelope of\r\na telegram. She immediately took leave to open this missive, after\r\nthe quick perusal of which she had another vision of them all. \xe2\x80\x9cIt IS\r\nshe--the modern daughter. \xe2\x80\x98Tishy keeps me dinner and opera; clothes\r\nall right; return uncertain, but if before morning have latch-key.\xe2\x80\x99 She\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t come home till morning!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Brook.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut think of the comfort of the latch-key!\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nmight go to the opera,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Mr. Longdon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHanged if _I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Cashmore exclaimed.\r\n\r\nMr. Longdon appeared to have caught from Nanda\xe2\x80\x99s message an obscure\r\nagitation; he met his young friend\xe2\x80\x99s suggestion at all events with a\r\nvisible intensity. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you go with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank had just debated, recalling engagements; which gave Mrs.\r\nBrook time to intervene. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you live without him?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked of her\r\nelder friend.\r\n\r\nVanderbank had looked at her an instant. \xe2\x80\x9cI think I can get there late,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he then replied to Mr. Longdon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think _I_ can get there early,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Cashmore declared. \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Grendon\r\nmust have a box; in fact I know which, and THEY don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d he jocosely\r\ncontinued to his hostess.\r\n\r\nMrs. Brook meanwhile had given Mr. Longdon her hand. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, in any case\r\nthe child SHALL soon come to you. And oh alone,\xe2\x80\x9d she insisted: \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nneedn\xe2\x80\x99t make phrases--I know too well what I\xe2\x80\x99m about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne hopes really you do,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the unquenched Mr. Cashmore.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf that\xe2\x80\x99s what one gets by having known your mother--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have helped YOU\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brook retorted. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd won\xe2\x80\x99t you have\r\nto say it\xe2\x80\x99s ALL you were to get?\xe2\x80\x9d she pityingly murmured to her other\r\nvisitor.\r\n\r\nHe turned to Vanderbank with a strange gasp, and that comforter said\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK FIFTH. THE DUCHESS\r\n\r\nThe lower windows of the great white house, which stood high and\r\nsquare, opened to a wide flagged terrace, the parapet of which, an old\r\nbalustrade of stone, was broken in the middle of its course by a flight\r\nof stone steps that descended to a wonderful garden. The terrace had the\r\nafternoon shade and fairly hung over the prospect that dropped away and\r\ncircled it--the prospect, beyond the series of gardens, of scattered\r\nsplendid trees and green glades, an horizon mainly of woods. Nanda\r\nBrookenham, one day at the end of July, coming out to find the place\r\nunoccupied as yet by other visitors, stood there a while with an air\r\nof happy possession. She moved from end to end of the terrace, pausing,\r\ngazing about her, taking in with a face that showed the pleasure of a\r\nbrief independence the combination of delightful things--of old rooms\r\nwith old decorations that gleamed and gloomed through the high windows,\r\nof old gardens that squared themselves in the wide angles of old walls,\r\nof wood-walks rustling in the afternoon breeze and stretching away\r\nto further reaches of solitude and summer. The scene had an expectant\r\nstillness that she was too charmed to desire to break; she watched it,\r\nlistened to it, followed with her eyes the white butterflies among the\r\nflowers below her, then gave a start as the cry of a peacock came to\r\nher from an unseen alley. It set her after a minute into less difficult\r\nmotion; she passed slowly down the steps, wandering further, looking\r\nback at the big bright house but pleased again to see no one else\r\nappear. If the sun was still high enough she had a pink parasol. She\r\nwent through the gardens one by one, skirting the high walls that were\r\nso like \xe2\x80\x9ccollections\xe2\x80\x9d and thinking how, later on, the nectarines and\r\nplums would flush there. She exchanged a friendly greeting with a man\r\nat work, passed through an open door and, turning this way and that,\r\nfinally found herself in the park, at some distance from the house. It\r\nwas a point she had had to take another rise to reach, a place marked\r\nby an old green bench for a larger sweep of the view, which, in the\r\ndistance where the woods stopped, showed in the most English way in the\r\nworld the colour-spot of an old red village and the tower of an old\r\ngrey church. She had sunk down upon the bench almost with a sense of\r\nadventure, yet not too fluttered to wonder if it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been\r\nhappy to bring a book; the charm of which precisely would have been in\r\nfeeling everything about her too beautiful to let her read.\r\n\r\nThe sense of adventure grew in her, presently becoming aware of a stir\r\nin the thicket below, followed by the coming into sight, on a path that,\r\nmounting, passed near her seat, of a wanderer whom, had his particular,\r\nhis exceptional identity not quickly appeared, it might have\r\ndisappointed her a trifle to have to recognise as a friend. He saw her\r\nimmediately, stopped, laughed, waved his hat, then bounded up the slope\r\nand, brushing his forehead with his handkerchief, confessing as to a\r\nred face, was rejoicingly there before her. Her own ejaculation on first\r\nseeing him--\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Mr. Van!\xe2\x80\x9d--had had an ambiguous sharpness that was\r\nrather for herself than for her visitor. She made room for him on\r\nthe bench, where in a moment he was cooling off and they were both\r\nexplaining. The great thing was that he had walked from the station to\r\nstretch his legs, coming far round, for the lovely hour and the pleasure\r\nof it, by a way he had learnt on some previous occasion of being at\r\nMertle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve already stayed here then?\xe2\x80\x9d Nanda, who had arrived but half\r\nan hour before, spoke as if she had lost the chance to give him a new\r\nimpression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve stayed here--yes, but not with Mitchy; with some people or\r\nother--who the deuce can they have been?--who had the place for a few\r\nmonths a year or two ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you even remember?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank wondered and laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will come to me. But it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ncharming sign of London relations, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?--that one CAN come down to\r\npeople this way and be awfully well \xe2\x80\x98done for\xe2\x80\x99 and all that, and then\r\ngo away and lose the whole thing, quite forget to whom one has been\r\nbeholden. It\xe2\x80\x99s a queer life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda seemed for an instant to wish to say that one might deny the\r\nqueerness, but she said something else instead. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose a man\r\nlike you doesn\xe2\x80\x99t quite feel that he IS beholden. It\xe2\x80\x99s awfully good of\r\nhim--it\xe2\x80\x99s doing a great deal for anybody--that he should come down at\r\nall; so that it would add immensely to his burden if anybody had to be\r\nremembered for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what you mean by a man \xe2\x80\x98like me,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank returned.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not any particular kind of a man.\xe2\x80\x9d She had been looking at him, but\r\nshe looked away on this, and he continued good-humoured and explanatory.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you mean that I go about such a lot, how do you know it but by the\r\nfact that you\xe2\x80\x99re everywhere now yourself?--so that, whatever I am, in\r\nshort, you\xe2\x80\x99re just as bad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou admit then that you ARE everywhere. I may be just as bad,\xe2\x80\x9d the girl\r\nwent on, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the point is that I\xe2\x80\x99m not nearly so good. Girls are such\r\nnatural hacks--they can\xe2\x80\x99t be anything else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd pray what are fellows who are in the beastly grind of fearfully\r\nbusy offices? There isn\xe2\x80\x99t an old cabhorse in London that\xe2\x80\x99s kept at it,\r\nI assure you, as I am. Besides,\xe2\x80\x9d the young man added, \xe2\x80\x9cif I\xe2\x80\x99m out every\r\nnight and off somewhere like this for Sunday, can\xe2\x80\x99t you understand, my\r\ndear child, the fundamental reason of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda, with her eyes on him again, studied an instant this mystery.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I to infer with delight that it\xe2\x80\x99s the sweet hope of meeting ME? It\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued in a moment, \xe2\x80\x9cas if there were any necessity\r\nfor your saying that. What\xe2\x80\x99s the use?\xe2\x80\x9d But all impatiently she stopped\r\nshort.\r\n\r\nHe was eminently gay even if his companion was not. \xe2\x80\x9cBecause we\xe2\x80\x99re such\r\njolly old friends that we really needn\xe2\x80\x99t so much as speak at all? Yes,\r\nthank goodness--thank goodness.\xe2\x80\x9d He had been looking round him, taking\r\nin the scene; he had dropped his hat on the ground and, completely at\r\nhis ease, though still more wishing to show it, had crossed his legs and\r\nclosely folded his arms. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a tremendously jolly place! This\r\nyoung lady, established in the pleasant shade on a sofa of light\r\nconstruction designed for the open air, offered the image of a patience\r\nof which it was a questionable kindness to break the spell. It was that\r\nbeautiful hour when, toward the close of the happiest days of summer,\r\nsuch places as the great terrace at Mertle present to the fancy a recall\r\nof the banquet-hall deserted--deserted by the company lately gathered at\r\ntea and now dispersed, according to affinities and combinations promptly\r\nfelt and perhaps quite as promptly criticised, either in quieter\r\nchambers where intimacy might deepen or in gardens and under trees where\r\nthe stillness knew the click of balls and the good humour of games.\r\nThere had been chairs, on the terrace, pushed about; there were\r\nungathered teacups on the level top of the parapet; the servants in\r\nfact, in the manner of \xe2\x80\x9chands\xe2\x80\x9d mustered by a whistle on the deck of a\r\nship, had just arrived to restore things to an order soon again to be\r\nbroken. A tantot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she passed into the house by the nearest of the long windows that\r\nstood open Mr. Longdon placed himself beside her little charge, whom he\r\ntreated, for the next ten minutes, with an exquisite courtesy. A person\r\nwho knew him well would, if present at the scene, have found occasion\r\nin it to be freshly aware that he was in his quiet way master of two\r\ndistinct kinds of urbanity, the kind that added to distance and the kind\r\nthat diminished it. Such an analyst would furthermore have noted, in\r\nrespect to the aunt and the niece, of which kind each had the benefit,\r\nand might even have gone so far as to detect in him some absolute\r\nbetrayal of the impression produced on him by his actual companion, some\r\nirradiation of his certitude that, from the point of view under which\r\nshe had been formed, she was a remarkable, a rare success. Since to\r\ncreate a particular little rounded and tinted innocence had been aimed\r\nat, the fruit had been grown to the perfection of a peach on a sheltered\r\nwall, and this quality of the object resulting from a process might well\r\nmake him feel himself in contact with something wholly new. Little Aggie\r\ndiffered from any young person he had ever met in that she had been\r\ndeliberately prepared for consumption and in that furthermore the\r\ngentleness of her spirit had immensely helped the preparation. Nanda,\r\nbeside her, was a Northern savage, and the reason was partly that the\r\nelements of that young lady\xe2\x80\x99s nature were already, were publicly, were\r\nalmost indecorously active. They were practically there for good or for\r\nill; experience was still to come and what they might work out to still\r\na mystery; but the sum would get itself done with the figures now on the\r\nslate. On little Aggie\xe2\x80\x99s slate the figures were yet to be written; which\r\nsufficiently accounted for the difference of the two surfaces. Both\r\nthe girls struck him as lambs with the great shambles of life in\r\ntheir future; but while one, with its neck in a pink ribbon, had no\r\nconsciousness but that of being fed from the hand with the small sweet\r\nbiscuit of unobjectionable knowledge, the other struggled with instincts\r\nand forebodings, with the suspicion of its doom and the far-borne scent,\r\nin the flowery fields, of blood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh Nanda, she\xe2\x80\x99s my best friend after three or four others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter so many?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Longdon laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think that\xe2\x80\x99s rather a\r\nback seat, as they say, for one\xe2\x80\x99s best?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA back seat?\xe2\x80\x9d--she wondered with a purity!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said her companion, \xe2\x80\x9cit serves me right, as\r\nyour aunt didn\xe2\x80\x99t leave me with you to teach you the slang of the day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98slang\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d--she again spotlessly speculated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve never even heard the expression? Formed to express\r\neverything, it scarce expressed as yet even a consciousness. All the\r\nelements of play were in it, but they had nothing to play with. When the elephant in the show plays the fiddle it\r\nmust be mainly with the presumption of consequent apples; which was\r\nwhy, doubtless, this personage had half the time the air of assuring\r\nyou that, really civilised as his type had now become, no apples were\r\nrequired. Somehow he\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t positively up. More evidence would be needed to decide; yet\r\nit was just of more evidence that one remained rather in dread. The strangest part of the impression too\r\nwas that the provision might really have its happy side and his lordship\r\nunderstand definitely better than any one else his noble friend\xe2\x80\x99s whole\r\ntheory of perils and precautions. The child herself, the spectator of\r\nthe incident was sure enough, understood nothing; but the understandings\r\nthat surrounded her, filling all the air, made it a heavier compound to\r\nbreathe than any Mr. Longdon had yet tasted. This heaviness had grown\r\nfor him through the long sweet summer day, and there was something in\r\nhis at last finding himself ensconced with the Duchess that made it\r\nsupremely oppressive. The contact was one that, none the less, he would\r\nnot have availed himself of a decent pretext to avoid. With so many\r\nfine mysteries playing about him there was relief, at the point he had\r\nreached, rather than alarm, in the thought of knowing the worst; which\r\nit pressed upon him somehow that the Duchess must not only altogether\r\nknow but must in any relation quite naturally communicate. It fluttered\r\nhim rather that a person who had an understanding with Lord Petherton\r\nshould so single him out as to wish for one also with himself; such a\r\nperson must either have great variety of mind or have a wonderful idea\r\nof HIS variety. It was true indeed that Mr. Mitchett must have the most\r\nextraordinary understanding, and yet with Mr. Mitchett he now found\r\nhimself quite pleasantly at his ease. Their host, however, was a person\r\nsui generis, whom he had accepted, once for all, the inconsequence of\r\nliking in conformity with the need he occasionally felt to put it on\r\nrecord that he was not narrow-minded. Perhaps at bottom he most liked\r\nMitchy because Mitchy most liked Nanda; there hung about him still\r\nmoreover the faded fragrance of the superstition that hospitality not\r\ndeclined is one of the things that \xe2\x80\x9coblige.\xe2\x80\x9d It obliged the thoughts,\r\nfor Mr. Longdon, as well as the manners, and in the especial form in\r\nwhich he was now committed to it would have made him, had he really\r\nthought any ill, ask himself what the deuce then he was doing in\r\nthe man\xe2\x80\x99s house. It\xe2\x80\x99s rather important.\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank\r\nexpressed on the spot the liveliest desire to oblige him and, quickly\r\nlighting another cigarette, mounted again to the deep divan with which\r\na part of the place was furnished. The smoking-room at Mertle was not\r\nunworthy of the general nobleness, and the fastidious spectator had\r\nclearly been reckoned on in the great leather-covered lounge that,\r\nraised by a step or two above the floor, applied its back to two\r\nquarters of the wall and enjoyed most immediately a view of the\r\nbilliard-table. Vanderbank,\r\nperched aloft on the bench and awaiting developments, had a little the\r\nlook of some prepossessing criminal who, in court, should have changed\r\nplaces with the judge. He was unlike many a man of marked good looks\r\nin that the effect of evening dress was not, with a perversity often\r\nobserved in such cases, to over-emphasise his fineness. His type was\r\nrather chastened than heightened, and he sat there moreover with a\r\nprimary discretion quite in the note of the deference that from the\r\nfirst, with his friend of the elder fashion, he had taken as imposed.\r\nHe had a strong sense for shades of respect and was now careful to\r\nloll scarcely more than with an official superior. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you ask me,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr.\r\nLongdon presently continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy at this hour of the night--after a day\r\nat best too heterogeneous--I don\xe2\x80\x99t keep over till to-morrow whatever I\r\nmay have to say, I can only tell you that I appeal to you now because\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve something on my mind that I shall sleep the better for being rid\r\nof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was space to circulate in front of the haut-pas, where he had\r\nstill paced and still swung his glasses; but with these words he had\r\npaused, leaning against the billiard-table, to meet the interested\r\nurbanity of the answer they produced. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you very sure that having\r\ngot rid of it you WILL sleep? But it\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter. We all call everything--anything. If\r\nmy visit must commit me,\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank pursued, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I can\xe2\x80\x99t come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Longdon, who had passed into the corridor, gave a dry sad little\r\nlaugh. \xe2\x80\x9cCome then--as the ladies say--\xe2\x80\x98as you are\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn which, rather softly closing the door, the young man remained alone\r\nin the great emptily lighted billiard-room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK SIXTH. MRS. BROOK\r\n\r\n\r\nPresenting himself at Buckingham Crescent three days after the Sunday\r\nspent at Mertle, Vanderbank found Lady Fanny Cashmore in the act of\r\ntaking leave of Mrs. Brook and found Mrs. Brook herself in the state of\r\nmuffled exaltation that was the mark of all her intercourse--and most\r\nof all perhaps of her farewells--with Lady Fanny. This splendid creature\r\ngave out, as it were, so little that Vanderbank was freshly struck\r\nwith all Mrs. Brook could take in, though nothing, for that matter, in\r\nBuckingham Crescent, had been more fully formulated on behalf of the\r\nfamous beauty than the imperturbable grandeur of her almost total\r\nabsence of articulation. Every aspect of the phenomenon had been freely\r\ndiscussed there and endless ingenuity lavished on the question of how\r\nexactly it was that so much of what the world would in another case have\r\ncalled complete stupidity could be kept by a mere wonderful face from\r\nboring one to death. It was Mrs. Brook who, in this relation as in many\r\nothers, had arrived at the supreme expression of the law, had thrown\r\noff, happily enough, to whomever it might have concerned: \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear\r\nthing, it all comes back, as everything always does, simply to personal\r\npluck. It\xe2\x80\x99s only a question, no matter when or where, of having enough.\r\nLady Fanny has the courage of all her silence--so much therefore that\r\nit sees her completely through and is what really makes her interesting.\r\nNot to be afraid of what may happen to you when you\xe2\x80\x99ve no more to say\r\nfor yourself than a steamer without a light--that truly is the highest\r\nheroism, and Lady Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s greatness is that she\xe2\x80\x99s never afraid. She\r\ntakes the risk every time she goes out--takes, as you may say, her life\r\nin her hand. She just turns that glorious mask upon you and practically\r\nsays: \xe2\x80\x98No, I won\xe2\x80\x99t open my lips--to call it really open--for the forty\r\nminutes I shall stay; but I calmly defy you, all the same, to kill me\r\nfor it.\xe2\x80\x99 And we don\xe2\x80\x99t kill her--we delight in her; though when either of\r\nus watches her in a circle of others it\xe2\x80\x99s like seeing a very large blind\r\nperson in the middle of Oxford Street. One fairly looks about for the\r\npolice.\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank, before his fellow visitor withdrew it, had the\r\nbenefit of the glorious mask and could scarce have failed to be amused\r\nat the manner in which Mrs. Brook alone showed the stress of thought.\r\nLady Fanny, in the other scale, sat aloft and Olympian, so that though\r\nvisibly much had happened between the two ladies it had all happened\r\nonly to the hostess. The sense in the air in short was just of Lady\r\nFanny herself, who came to an end like a banquet or a procession.\r\nMrs. Brook left the room with her and, on coming back, was full of it.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll go, she\xe2\x80\x99ll go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo where?\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank appeared to have for the question less attention\r\nthan usual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, to the place her companion will propose. Probably--like Anna\r\nKarenine--to one of the smaller Italian towns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnna Karenine? She isn\xe2\x80\x99t a bit like Anna.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course she isn\xe2\x80\x99t so clever,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Brook. \xe2\x80\x9cBut that would spoil\r\nher. So it\xe2\x80\x99s all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad it\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I dare say we shall\r\nstill have her with us a while.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall do that, I trust, whatever happens. She\xe2\x80\x99ll come up\r\nagain--she\xe2\x80\x99ll remain, I feel, one of those enormous things that fate\r\nseems somehow to have given me as the occupation of my odd moments. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t see,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brook added, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat still keeps her on the edge, which\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t an inch wide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank looked this time as if he only tried to wonder. \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it\r\nYOU?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brook mused more deeply. \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes I think so. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, how CAN you of course know, since she can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh if I depended on her telling--!\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brook shook out with this\r\na sofa-cushion or two and sank into the corner she had arranged. The\r\nAugust afternoon was hot and the London air heavy; the room moreover,\r\nthough agreeably bedimmed, gave out the staleness of the season\xe2\x80\x99s end.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you hadn\xe2\x80\x99t come to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d have missed me till I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know when, for we\xe2\x80\x99ve let the Hovel again--wretchedly, but still\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ve let it--and I go down on Friday to see that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t too filthy.\r\nEdward, who\xe2\x80\x99s furious at what I\xe2\x80\x99ve taken for it, had his idea that we\r\nshould go there this year ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now\xe2\x80\x9d--Vanderbank took her up--\xe2\x80\x9cthat fond fancy has become simply\r\nthe ghost of a dead thought, a ghost that, in company with a thousand\r\npredecessors, haunts the house in the twilight and pops at you out of\r\nodd corners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh Edward\xe2\x80\x99s dead thoughts are indeed a cheerful company and worthy of\r\nthe perpetual mental mourning we seem to go about in. They\xe2\x80\x99re worse than\r\nthe relations we\xe2\x80\x99re always losing without seeming to have any fewer,\r\nand I expect every day to hear that the Morning Post regrets to have\r\nto announce in that line too some new bereavement. The apparitions\r\nfollowing the deaths of so many thoughts ARE particularly awful in the\r\ntwilight, so that at this season, while the day drags and drags, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nglad to have any one with me who may keep them at a distance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank had not sat down; slowly, familiarly he turned about. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nwhere\xe2\x80\x99s Nanda?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh SHE doesn\xe2\x80\x99t help--she attracts rather the worst of the bogies.\r\nEdward and Nanda and Harold and I seated together are fairly a case for\r\nthat--what do you call it?--investigating Society. Deprived of the sweet\r\nresource of the Hovel,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brook continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall each, from about\r\nthe tenth on, forage somehow or other for ourselves. Mitchy perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n she added, \xe2\x80\x9cwill insist on taking us to Baireuth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be the form, you mean, of his own forage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brook just hesitated. \xe2\x80\x9cUnless you should prefer to take it as the\r\nform of yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank appeared for a moment obligingly enough to turn this over,\r\nbut with the effect of noting an objection. \xe2\x80\x9cOh I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I shall have\r\nto grind straight through the month and that by the time I\xe2\x80\x99m free every\r\nRing at Baireuth will certainly have been rung. Is it your idea to take\r\nNanda?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nShe reached out for another cushion. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible for you to\r\nmanage what I suggest why should that question interest you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear woman\xe2\x80\x9d--and her visitor dropped into a chair--\xe2\x80\x9cdo you suppose\r\nmy interest depends on such poverties as what I can \xe2\x80\x98manage\xe2\x80\x99? You know\r\nwell enough,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on in another tone, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy I care for Nanda and\r\nenquire about her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was perfectly ready. \xe2\x80\x9cI know it, but only as a bad reason. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\ntoo sure!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a moment they looked at each other. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be so sure, you mean,\r\nthat the elation of it may go to my head? Are you really warning me\r\nagainst vanity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour \xe2\x80\x98reallys,\xe2\x80\x99 my dear Van, are a little formidable, but it strikes\r\nme that before I tell you there\xe2\x80\x99s something I\xe2\x80\x99ve a right to ask. I don\xe2\x80\x99t quite see moreover why you speak as if\r\nI were paying an abrupt and unnatural attention. What have I done the\r\nlast three months but talk to you about her? From the moment you first spoke to me--\xe2\x80\x98monstrously,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nI remember you called it--of the difference made in your social life by\r\nher finally established, her perpetual, her inexorable participation:\r\nfrom that moment what have we both done but put our heads together over\r\nthe question of keeping the place tidy, as you called it--or as _I_\r\ncalled it, was it?--for the young female mind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brook faced serenely enough the directness of this challenge.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what are you coming to? I spoke of the change in my life of\r\ncourse; I happen to be so constituted that my life has something to do\r\nwith my mind and my mind something to do with my talk. Good talk: you\r\nknow--no one, dear Van, should know better--what part for me that plays.\r\nTherefore when one has deliberately to make one\xe2\x80\x99s talk bad--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Bad\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank, in his amusement, fell back in his chair. \xe2\x80\x9cDear\r\nMrs. Brook, you\xe2\x80\x99re too delightful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know what I mean--stupid, flat, fourth-rate. He won\xe2\x80\x99t go in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIII\r\n\r\nHer visitors had been gone half an hour, but she was still in the\r\ndrawing-room when Nanda came back. The recurrence\r\nof opportunity to observe them together would have taught a spectator\r\nthat--on Mrs. Brook\xe2\x80\x99s side doubtless more particularly--their relation\r\nwas governed by two or three remarkably established and, as might have\r\nbeen said, refined laws, the spirit of which was to guard against the\r\nvulgarity so often coming to the surface between parent and child. He\xe2\x80\x99s too used to it--or too many things\r\nthat are too different now cover it up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Brook as she took this in, \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99s awfully\r\nclever of you to get only the good of him and have none of the worry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda wondered. \xe2\x80\x9cThe worry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou leave that all to ME,\xe2\x80\x9d her mother went on, but quite forgivingly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope at any rate that the good, for you, will be real.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReal?\xe2\x80\x9d the girl, remaining vague, again echoed.\r\n\r\nMrs. Brook showed for this not perhaps an irritation, but a flicker of\r\nausterity. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must remember we\xe2\x80\x99ve a great many things to think about.\r\nThere are things we must take for granted in each other--we must all\r\nhelp in our way to pull the coach. That\xe2\x80\x99s what I mean by worry, and if\r\nyou don\xe2\x80\x99t have any so much the better for you. For me it\xe2\x80\x99s in the day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwork. Your father and I have most to think about always at this time, as\r\nyou perfectly know--when we have to turn things round and manage somehow\r\nor other to get out of town, have to provide and pinch, to meet all the\r\nnecessities, with money, money, money at every turn running away like\r\nwater. The children this year seem to fit into nothing, into nowhere,\r\nand Harold\xe2\x80\x99s more dreadful than he has ever been, doing nothing at all\r\nfor himself and requiring everything to be done for him. He talks about\r\nhis American girl, with millions, who\xe2\x80\x99s so awfully taken with him, but\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t find out anything about her: the only one, just now, that people\r\nseem to have heard of is the one Booby Manger\xe2\x80\x99s engaged to. Baron Schack or\r\nSchmack--who has just taken Cumberland House and who has the awful\r\nstammer--or what is it? no roof to his mouth--is to give that horrid\r\nlittle Algie, to do his conversation for him, four hundred a year, which\r\nHarold pretended to me that, of all the rush of young men--dozens!--HE\r\nwas most in the running for. Your father\xe2\x80\x99s settled gloom is terrible,\r\nand I bear all the brunt of it; we get literally nothing this year for\r\nthe Hovel, yet have to spend on it heaven knows what; and everybody, for\r\nthe next three months, in Scotland and everywhere, has asked us for the\r\nwrong time and nobody for the right: so that I assure you I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwhere to turn--which doesn\xe2\x80\x99t however in the least prevent every one\r\ncoming to me with their own selfish troubles.\xe2\x80\x9d It was as if Mrs. Brook\r\nhad found the cup of her secret sorrows suddenly jostled by some touch\r\nof which the perversity, though not completely noted at the moment,\r\nproved, as she a little let herself go, sufficient to make it flow over;\r\nbut she drew, the next thing, from her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s stillness a reflexion\r\nof the vanity of such heat and speedily recovered herself as if in order\r\nwith more dignity to point the moral. \xe2\x80\x9cI can carry my burden and shall\r\ndo so to the end; but we must each remember that we shall fall to pieces\r\nif we don\xe2\x80\x99t manage to keep hold of some little idea of responsibility. I\r\npositively can\xe2\x80\x99t arrange without knowing when it is you go to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Mr. Longdon? I mean would he hate it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think so at all, but I can easily ask him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brook\xe2\x80\x99s head inclined to the chimney and her eyes to the window.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEasily?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda looked for a moment mystified by her mother\xe2\x80\x99s insistence. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\r\nat any rate perfectly try it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemembering even that mamma would never have pushed so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda\xe2\x80\x99s face seemed to concede even that condition. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d she at all\r\nevents serenely replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI really think we\xe2\x80\x99re good friends enough for\r\nanything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt might have been, for the light it quickly produced, exactly what her\r\nmother had been working to make her say. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you call that then, I\r\nshould like to know, but his adopting you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that it matters much what it\xe2\x80\x99s called.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo long as it brings with it, you mean,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brook asked, \xe2\x80\x9call the\r\nadvantages?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nanda, who had now begun dimly to smile--\xe2\x80\x9ccall them\r\nadvantages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Brook had a pause. \xe2\x80\x9cOne would be quite ready to do that if one only\r\nknew a little more exactly what they\xe2\x80\x99re to consist of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh the great advantage, I feel, is doing something for HIM.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda\xe2\x80\x99s companion, at this, hesitated afresh. \xe2\x80\x9cBut doesn\xe2\x80\x99t that, my\r\ndear, put the extravagance of your surrender to him on rather an odd\r\nfooting? Her\r\ndomestic despair centred at this instant all in her daughter. \xe2\x80\x9cWell\r\nthen, we shall consider--your father and I--that he must take the\r\nconsequence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda had now her hand on the door, while Harold had dropped on the\r\nsofa. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d she just sounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean Mr. Longdon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you mean by the consequence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it will do for the beginning of it that you\xe2\x80\x99ll please go down\r\nWITH him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn Saturday then? This, after an instant, as she approached the sofa and raised her\r\neyes from the little table beside it, came straight out. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere in the\r\nworld is that five-pound note?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHarold looked vacantly about him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat five-pound note?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK SEVENTH. MITCHY\r\n\r\nMr. Longdon\xe2\x80\x99s garden took in three acres and, full of charming features,\r\nhad for its greatest wonder the extent and colour of its old brick wall,\r\nin which the pink and purple surface was the fruit of the mild ages\r\nand the protective function, for a visitor strolling, sitting, talking,\r\nreading, that of a nurse of reverie. The air of the place, in the August\r\ntime, thrilled all the while with the bliss of birds, the hum of little\r\nlives unseen and the flicker of white butterflies. It was on the large\r\nflat enclosed lawn that Nanda spoke to Vanderbank of the three weeks she\r\nwould have completed there on the morrow--weeks that had been--she made\r\nno secret of it--the happiest she had yet spent anywhere. The greyish\r\nday was soft and still and the sky faintly marbled, while the more newly\r\narrived of the visitors from London, who had come late on the Friday\r\nafternoon, lounged away the morning in an attitude every relaxed line\r\nof which referred to the holiday he had, as it were--at first merely\r\nlooking about and victualling--sat down in front of as a captain before\r\na city. There were sitting-places, just there, out of the full light,\r\ncushioned benches in the thick wide spread of old mulberry-boughs. A\r\nlarge book of facts lay in the young man\xe2\x80\x99s lap, and Nanda had come out\r\nto him, half an hour before luncheon, somewhat as Beatrice came out to\r\nBenedick: not to call him immediately indeed to the meal, but mentioning\r\npromptly that she had come at a bidding. Mr. Longdon had rebuked her, it\r\nappeared, for her want of attention to their guest, showing her in\r\nthis way, to her pleasure, how far he had gone toward taking her, as he\r\ncalled it, into the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking of yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank asked, \xe2\x80\x9cas a mere clerk\r\nat a salary, and you now find that you\xe2\x80\x99re a partner and have a share in\r\nthe concern?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to be something like that. But doesn\xe2\x80\x99t a partner put in\r\nsomething? What have I put in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell--ME, for one thing. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it your being here that has brought me\r\ndown?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have come for him alone? Then don\xe2\x80\x99t you make\r\nanything of his attraction? You ought to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nanda, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen he likes\r\nyou so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank, longing for a river, was in white flannels, and he took\r\nher question with a happy laugh, a handsome face of good humour that\r\ncompleted the effect of his long, cool fairness. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you mind my just\r\nsitting still, do you mind letting me smoke and staying with me a while?\r\nPerhaps after a little we\xe2\x80\x99ll walk about--shan\xe2\x80\x99t we? But face to face\r\nwith this dear old house, in this jolly old nook, one\xe2\x80\x99s too contented\r\nto move, lest raising a finger even should break the spell. What WILL be\r\nperfect will be your just sitting down--DO sit down--and scolding me a\r\nlittle. That, my dear Nanda, will deepen the peace.\xe2\x80\x9d Some minutes later,\r\nwhile, near him but in another chair, she fingered the impossible book,\r\nas she pronounced it, that she had taken from him, he came back to what\r\nshe had last said. \xe2\x80\x9cHas he talked to you much about his \xe2\x80\x98liking\xe2\x80\x99 me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda waited a minute, turning over the book. \xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen how are you just now so struck with it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not struck only with what I\xe2\x80\x99m talked to about. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nwent on, \xe2\x80\x9conly what people tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh no--you\xe2\x80\x99re too much your mother\xe2\x80\x99s daughter for that!\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank\r\nleaned back and smoked, and though all his air seemed to say that when\r\none was so at ease for gossip almost any subject would do, he kept\r\njogging his foot with the same small nervous motion as during the\r\nhalf-hour at Mertle that this record has commemorated. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re too\r\nmuch one of us all,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve tremendous perceptions,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course I SHOULD have come for him. This was a\r\nconsiderable space--in the little world at least of Suffolk--and the\r\nlook of possession had everywhere mixed with it, in the form of old\r\nwindows and doors, the tone of old red surfaces, the style of old white\r\nfacings, the age of old high creepers, the long confirmation of time.\r\nSuggestive of panelled rooms, of precious mahogany, of portraits\r\nof women dead, of coloured china glimmering through glass doors and\r\ndelicate silver reflected on bared tables, the thing was one of those\r\nimpressions of a particular period that it takes two centuries to\r\nproduce. \xe2\x80\x9cFancy,\xe2\x80\x9d the young man incoherently exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9chis caring to\r\nleave anything so loveable as all this to come up and live with US!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl also for a little lost herself. \xe2\x80\x9cOh you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it\r\nis--the charm comes out so as one stays. Every day I make\r\ndiscoveries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank wondered as he smoked. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mean he lets you take things--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes--up to my room, to study or to copy. Mr.\r\nCashmore knew her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank\xe2\x80\x99s smoke-puffs were profuse and his pauses frequent. \xe2\x80\x9cAwful\r\nto Mr. Cashmore? The windows of the drawing-room\r\nlooked at the wet garden, all vivid and rich in the summer shower, and\r\nMitchy, after seeing Vanderbank turn up his trousers and fling back\r\na last answer to the not quite sincere chaff his submission had\r\nengendered, adopted freely and familiarly the prospect not only of a\r\ngrateful freshened lawn, but of a good hour in the very pick, as he\r\ncalled it, of his actual happy conditions. All this would have\r\nbeen a wonderful theme for discourse in Buckingham Crescent--so happy an\r\nexercise for the votaries of that temple of analysis that he repeatedly\r\nspoke of their experience of it as crying aloud for Mrs. Brook. Mr. Longdon had for the\r\nSunday dinner invited three or four of his neighbours to \xe2\x80\x9cmeet\xe2\x80\x9d the two\r\ngentlemen from town, so that it was not till the company had departed,\r\nor in other words till near bedtime, that our four friends could again\r\nhave become aware, as between themselves, of that directness of mutual\r\nrelation which forms the subject of our picture.
