For the others it\xe2\x80\x99s such an odd preparation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind it!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitchy declared.\r\n\r\nVanderbank visibly demurred. \xe2\x80\x9cAh but your choice--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs such a different sort of thing?\xe2\x80\x9d Mitchy, for the half-hour, in the\r\nambiguous dusk, had never looked more droll. \xe2\x80\x9cThe young lady I named\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t my CHOICE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, that\xe2\x80\x99s only a sign the more that you do these things more\r\neasily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh \xe2\x80\x98easily\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitchy murmured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t at any rate to keep it up,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vanderbank, who had looked\r\nat his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cTwelve twenty-five--good-night. Shall I blow out the\r\ncandles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo, please. I\xe2\x80\x99ll close the window\xe2\x80\x9d--and Mitchy went to it. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll follow\r\nyou--good-night.\xe2\x80\x9d The candles after a minute were out and his friend\r\nhad gone, but Mitchy, left in darkness face to face with the vague quiet\r\ngarden, still stood there.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK EIGHTH. TISHY GRENDON\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI\r\n\r\nThe footman, opening the door, mumbled his name without sincerity,\r\nand Vanderbank, passing in, found in fact--for he had caught the\r\nsymptom--the chairs and tables, the lighted lamps and the flowers alone\r\nin possession. He looked at his watch, which exactly marked eight, then\r\nturned to speak again to the servant, who had, however, without another\r\nsound and as if blushing for the house, already closed him in. There was\r\nnothing indeed but Mrs. Grendon\xe2\x80\x99s want of promptness that failed of a\r\nwelcome: her drawing-room, on the January night, showed its elegance\r\nthrough a suffusion of pink electricity which melted, at the end of\r\nthe vista, into the faintly golden glow of a retreat still more sacred.\r\nVanderbank walked after a moment into the second room, which also proved\r\nempty and which had its little globes of white fire--discreetly limited\r\nin number--coated with lemon-coloured silk. The walls, covered with\r\ndelicate French mouldings, were so fair that they seemed vaguely\r\nsilvered; the low French chimney had a French fire. There was a\r\nlemon-coloured stuff on the sofa and chairs, a wonderful polish on the\r\nfloor that was largely exposed, and a copy of a French novel in blue\r\npaper on one of the spindle-legged tables. Vanderbank looked about him\r\nan instant as if generally struck, then gave himself to something that\r\nhad particularly caught his eye. This was simply his own name written\r\nrather large on the cover of the French book and endowed, after he\r\nhad taken the volume up, with the power to hold his attention the\r\nmore closely the longer he looked at it. He uttered, for a private\r\nsatisfaction, before letting the matter pass, a low confused sound;\r\nafter which, flinging the book down with some emphasis in another place,\r\nhe moved to the chimney-piece, where his eyes for a little intently\r\nfixed the small ashy wood-fire. When he raised them again it was, on the\r\nobservation that the beautiful clock on the mantel was wrong, to consult\r\nonce more his watch and then give a glance, in the chimney-glass, at the\r\nstate of his moustache, the ends of which he twisted for a moment\r\nwith due care. While so engaged he became aware of something else and,\r\nquickly facing about, recognised in the doorway of the room the other\r\nfigure the glass had just reflected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh YOU?\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a quick handshake. \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Grendon\xe2\x80\x99s down?\xe2\x80\x9d But he\r\nhad already passed with Nanda, on their greeting, back into the first\r\nroom, which contained only themselves, and she had mentioned that she\r\nbelieved Tishy to have said 8.15, which meant of course anything people\r\nliked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh then there\xe2\x80\x99ll be nobody till nine. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t, I suppose, sufficiently\r\nstudy my note; which didn\xe2\x80\x99t mention to me, by the way,\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank\r\nadded, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you were to be here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh but why SHOULD it?\xe2\x80\x9d Nanda spoke again, however, before he could\r\nreply. \xe2\x80\x9cI dare say that when she wrote to you she didn\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnow you\xe2\x80\x99d come bang up to meet me?\xe2\x80\x9d Vanderbank laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cJolly at any\r\nrate, thanks to my mistake, to have in this way a quiet moment with you.\r\nYou came on ahead of your mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no--I\xe2\x80\x99m staying here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Vanderbank.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Longdon came up with me--I came here, Friday last, straight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou parted at the door?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked with marked gaiety.\r\n\r\nShe thought a moment--she was more serious. \xe2\x80\x9cYes--but only for a day or\r\ntwo. He\xe2\x80\x99s coming tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood. How delightful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll be glad to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d Nanda said, looking at the flowers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAwfully kind of him when I\xe2\x80\x99ve been such a brute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow--a brute?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I mean not writing--nor going back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh I see,\xe2\x80\x9d Nanda simply returned.\r\n\r\nIt was a simplicity that, clearly enough, made her friend a little\r\nawkward. \xe2\x80\x9cHas he--a--minded? VANDERBANK\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you had better wait,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Brook said, \xe2\x80\x9ctill I see if he has\r\ngone;\xe2\x80\x9d and on the arrival the next moment of the servants with the\r\ntea she was able to put her question. \xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Cashmore still with Miss\r\nBrookenham?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d the footman replied. \xe2\x80\x9cI let Mr. Cashmore out five minutes\r\nago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVanderbank showed for the next short time by his behaviour what he felt\r\nat not yet being free to act on this; moving pointlessly about the room\r\nwhile the servants arranged the tea-table and taking no trouble to make,\r\nfor appearance, any other talk. I HAVE been in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but always with other people--you managed it somehow; the wrong\r\nones. NANDA\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI\r\n\r\nNanda Brookenham, for a fortnight after Mr. Longdon\xe2\x80\x99s return, had found\r\nmuch to think of; but the bustle of business became, visibly for us,\r\nparticularly great with her on a certain Friday afternoon in June. She\r\nwas in unusual possession of that chamber of comfort in which so much\r\nof her life had lately been passed, the redecorated and rededicated room\r\nupstairs in which she had enjoyed a due measure both of solitude and\r\nof society. Passing the objects about her in review she gave especial\r\nattention to her rather marked wealth of books; changed repeatedly, for\r\nfive minutes, the position of various volumes, transferred to tables\r\nthose that were on shelves and rearranged shelves with an eye to the\r\neffect of backs. She was flagrantly engaged throughout indeed in the\r\nstudy of effect, which moreover, had the law of an extreme freshness not\r\ninveterately prevailed there, might have been observed to be traceable\r\nin the very detail of her own appearance. \xe2\x80\x9cCompany\xe2\x80\x9d in short was in the\r\nair and expectation in the picture. The flowers on the little tables\r\nbloomed with a consciousness sharply taken up by the glitter of\r\nnick-nacks and reproduced in turn in the light exuberance of cushions\r\non sofas and the measured drop of blinds in windows. The numerous\r\nphotographed friends in particular were highly prepared, with small\r\nintense faces, each, that happened in every case to be turned to the\r\ndoor. The pair of eyes most dilated perhaps was that of old Van, present\r\nunder a polished glass and in a frame of gilt-edged morocco that spoke\r\nout, across the room, of Piccadilly and Christmas, and visibly widening\r\nhis gaze at the opening of the door, at the announcement of a name by a\r\nfootman and at the entrance of a gentleman remarkably like him save as\r\nthe resemblance was on the gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s part flattered. Vanderbank had\r\nnot been in the room ten seconds before he showed ever so markedly that\r\nhe had arrived to be kind. Kindness therefore becomes for us, by a quick\r\nturn of the glass that reflects the whole scene, the high pitch of the\r\nconcert--a kindness that almost immediately filled the place, to\r\nthe exclusion of everything else, with a familiar friendly voice, a\r\nbrightness of good looks and good intentions, a constant though perhaps\r\nsometimes misapplied laugh, a superabundance almost of interest,\r\ninattention and movement.\r\n\r\nThe first thing the young man said was that he was tremendously glad she\r\nhad written. \xe2\x80\x9cI think it was most particularly nice of you.\xe2\x80\x9d And this\r\nthought precisely seemed, as he spoke, a flower of the general bloom--as\r\nif the niceness he had brought in was so great that it straightway\r\nconverted everything to its image. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only thing that upset me a\r\nlittle,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cwas your saying that before writing it you had so\r\nhesitated and waited. I hope very much, you know, that you\xe2\x80\x99ll never do\r\nanything of that kind again. If you\xe2\x80\x99ve ever the slightest desire to see\r\nme--for no matter what reason, if there\xe2\x80\x99s ever the smallest thing of any\r\nsort that I can do for you, I promise you I shan\xe2\x80\x99t easily forgive you if\r\nyou stand on ceremony. It seems to me that when people have known each\r\nother as long as you and I there\xe2\x80\x99s one comfort at least they may treat\r\nthemselves to. I mean of course,\xe2\x80\x9d Van developed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat of being easy and\r\nfrank and natural. There are such a lot of relations in which one isn\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nin which it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pay, in which \xe2\x80\x98ease\xe2\x80\x99 in fact would be the greatest\r\nof troubles and \xe2\x80\x98nature\xe2\x80\x99 the greatest of falsities. However,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncontinued while he suddenly got up to change the place in which he had\r\nput his hat, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t really know why I\xe2\x80\x99m preaching at such a rate, for\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve a perfect consciousness of not myself requiring it. One does half\r\nthe time preach more or less for one\xe2\x80\x99s self, eh? I\xe2\x80\x99m not mistaken at all\r\nevents, I think, about the right thing with YOU. And a hint\xe2\x80\x99s enough\r\nfor you, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure, on the right thing with me.\xe2\x80\x9d He had been looking all\r\nround while he talked and had twice shifted his seat; so that it was\r\nquite in consonance with his general admiring notice that the next\r\nimpression he broke out with should have achieved some air of relevance.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat extraordinarily lovely flowers you have and how charming you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nmade everything! You\xe2\x80\x99re always doing something--women are always\r\nchanging the position of their furniture. If one happens to come in in\r\nthe dark, no matter how well one knows the place, one sits down on a\r\nhat or a puppy-dog. But of course you\xe2\x80\x99ll say one doesn\xe2\x80\x99t come in in the\r\ndark, or at least, if one does, deserves what one gets. Only you know\r\nthe way some women keep their rooms. I\xe2\x80\x99m bound to say YOU don\xe2\x80\x99t, do\r\nyou?--you don\xe2\x80\x99t go in for flower-pots in the windows and half a dozen\r\nblinds. Why SHOULD you? You HAVE got a lot to show!\xe2\x80\x9d He rose with this\r\nfor the third time, as the better to command the scene. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat I mean is\r\nthat sofa--which by the way is awfully good: you do, my dear Nanda, go\r\nit! It certainly was HERE the last time, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it? and this thing was\r\nthere. The last time--I mean the last time I was up here--was fearfully\r\nlong ago: when, by the way, WAS it? But you see I HAVE been and that\r\nI remember it. And you\xe2\x80\x99ve a lot more things now. You\xe2\x80\x99re laying up\r\ntreasure. Really the increase of luxury--! What an awfully jolly lot\r\nof books--have you read them all? Where did you learn so much about\r\nbindings?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe continued to talk; he took things up and put them down; Nanda sat in\r\nher place, where her stillness, fixed and colourless, contrasted with\r\nhis rather flushed freedom, and appeared only to wait, half in surprise,\r\nhalf in surrender, for the flow of his suggestiveness to run its course,\r\nso that, having herself provoked the occasion, she might do a little\r\nmore to meet it. It was by no means, however, that his presence in any\r\ndegree ceased to prevail; for there were minutes during which her face,\r\nthe only thing in her that moved, turning with his turns and following\r\nhis glances, actually had a look inconsistent with anything but\r\nsubmission to almost any accident. It might have expressed a desire for\r\nhis talk to last and last, an acceptance of any treatment of the hour\r\nor any version, or want of version, of her act that would best suit his\r\nease, even in fact a resigned prevision of the occurrence of something\r\nthat would leave her, quenched and blank, with the appearance of having\r\nmade him come simply that she might look at him. She might indeed well\r\nhave been aware of an inability to look at him little enough to make\r\nit flagrant that she had appealed to him for something quite different.\r\nKeeping the situation meanwhile thus in his hands he recognised over the\r\nchimney a new alteration. \xe2\x80\x9cThere used to be a big print--wasn\xe2\x80\x99t there?\r\na thing of the fifties--we had lots of them at home; some place or other\r\n\xe2\x80\x98in the olden time.\xe2\x80\x99 And now there\xe2\x80\x99s that lovely French glass. You ought to have a\r\nbird or two, though I dare say you think that by the noise I make I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nas good myself as a dozen. She\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nso fearfully young.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time at least her speech, while she went from point to point,\r\ncompletely hushed him, though after a full glimpse of the direction it\r\nwas taking he ceased to meet her eyes and only sat staring hard at the\r\npattern of the rug. And therefore it is I speak for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Longdon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I promised him I would.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d her friend repeated as in stifled pain.\r\n\r\nShe had kept for the time all her fine clearness turned to him; but\r\nshe might on this have been taken as giving him up with a movement of\r\nobedience and a strange soft sigh. The smothered sound might even have\r\nrepresented to a listener at all initiated a consenting retreat before\r\nan effort greater than her reckoning--a retreat that was in so far the\r\nsnap of a sharp tension. The next minute, none the less, she evidently\r\nfound a fresh provocation in the sight of the pale and positively\r\nexcessive rigour she had imposed, so that, though her friend was only\r\naccommodating himself to her wish she had a sudden impulse of criticism.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re proud about it--too proud!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what if I am?\xe2\x80\x9d He looked at her with a complexity of\r\ncommunication that no words could have meddled with. \xe2\x80\x9cPride\xe2\x80\x99s all right\r\nwhen it helps one to bear things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nanda, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that\xe2\x80\x99s only when one wants to take the least from\r\nthem. When one wants to take the most--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d--he spoke, as she faltered, with a certain small hardness of\r\ninterest.\r\n\r\nShe faltered, however, indeed. \xe2\x80\x9cOh I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to say it.\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\nfairly coloured with the attempt. \xe2\x80\x9cOne must let the sense of all that I\r\nspeak of--well, all come. One must rather like it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know--but I\r\nsuppose one must rather grovel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Longdon, though with visible reluctance, turned it over. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvery fine--but you\xe2\x80\x99re a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes--that must make a difference. But being a woman, in such a case,\r\nhas then,\xe2\x80\x9d Nanda went on, \xe2\x80\x9cits advantages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn this point perhaps her friend might presently have been taken as\r\nrelaxing. \xe2\x80\x9cIt strikes me that even at that the advantages are mainly for\r\nothers. I\xe2\x80\x99m glad, God knows, that you\xe2\x80\x99re not also a young man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen we\xe2\x80\x99re suited all round.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe had spoken with a promptitude that appeared again to act on him\r\nslightly as an irritant, for he met it--with more delay--by a long and\r\nderisive murmur. \xe2\x80\x9cOh MY pride--!\xe2\x80\x9d But this she in no manner took up;\r\nso that he was left for a little to his thoughts. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what you were\r\nplotting when you told me the other day that you wanted time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t plotting--though I was, I confess, trying to work things\r\nout. That particular idea of simply asking Mr. Van by letter to present\r\nhimself--that particular flight of fancy hadn\xe2\x80\x99t in fact then at all\r\noccurred to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt never occurred, I\xe2\x80\x99m bound to say, to ME,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Longdon. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nnever thought of writing to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good. But you haven\xe2\x80\x99t the reasons. I wanted to attack him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot about me, I hope to God!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Longdon, distinctly a little paler,\r\nrejoined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid. I think I had an instinct of how you would have taken\r\nTHAT. It was about mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said her visitor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has been worse to her than to you,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued. \xe2\x80\x9cBut he\xe2\x80\x99ll make\r\nit all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Longdon\xe2\x80\x99s attention retained its grimness. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he has such a remedy\r\nfor the more then, what has he for the less?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNanda, however, was but for an instant checked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh it\xe2\x80\x99s I who make it up to YOU. To mother, you see, there\xe2\x80\x99s no one\r\notherwise to make it up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis at first unmistakeably sounded to him too complicated for\r\nacceptance. But his face changed as light dawned. \xe2\x80\x9cThat puts it then\r\nthat you WILL come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll come if you\xe2\x80\x99ll take me as I am--which is what I must previously\r\nexplain to you: I mean more than I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever done before. But what HE\r\nmeans by what you call his remedy is my making you feel better about\r\nhimself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man gazed at her. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Your\xe2\x80\x99 doing it is too beautiful! And he\r\ncould really come to you for the purpose of asking you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl briskly, \xe2\x80\x9che came simply for the purpose of doing\r\nwhat he HAD to do. After my letter how could he not come? Then he met\r\nmost kindly what I said to him for mother and what he quite understood\r\nto be all my business with him; so that his appeal to me to plead with\r\nyou for--well, for his credit--was only thrown in because he had so good\r\na chance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis speech brought Mr. Longdon abruptly to his feet, but before she\r\ncould warn him again of the patience she continued to need he had\r\nalready, as if what she evoked for him left him too stupefied, dropped\r\nback into submission. \xe2\x80\x9cThe man stood there for you to render him a\r\nservice?--for you to help him and praise him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh but it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to go out of my way, don\xe2\x80\x99t you see? He knew you were\r\npresently to be here.\xe2\x80\x9d Her anxiety that he should understand gave her a\r\nrare strained smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI mustn\xe2\x80\x99t make--as a request from him--too much of\r\nit, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve not a doubt that, rather than that you should think any\r\nill of him for wishing me to say a word, he would gladly be left with\r\nwhatever bad appearance he may actually happen to have.\xe2\x80\x9d She pulled\r\nup on these words as with a quick sense of their really, by their mere\r\nsound, putting her in deeper; and could only give her friend one of the\r\nlooks that expressed: \xe2\x80\x9cIf I could trust you not to assent even more than\r\nI want, I should say \xe2\x80\x98You know what I mean!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d She allowed him at all\r\nevents--or tried to allow him--no time for uttered irony before going\r\non: \xe2\x80\x9cHe was everything you could have wished; quite as beautiful about\r\nYOU--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs about you?\xe2\x80\x9d--Mr. Longdon took her up.\r\n\r\nShe demurred. \xe2\x80\x9cAs about mother.\xe2\x80\x9d With which she turned away as if it\r\nhandsomely settled the question.\r\n\r\nBut it only left him, as she went to the window, sitting there sombre.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d he brought out as his eyes followed her, \xe2\x80\x9cyour\r\nsaying you\xe2\x80\x99re not proud! Thank God you ARE, my dear. Yes--it\xe2\x80\x99s better\r\nfor us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this, after a moment, in her place, she turned round to him. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nglad I\xe2\x80\x99m anything--whatever you may call it and though I can\xe2\x80\x99t call it\r\nthe same--that\xe2\x80\x99s good for YOU.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said nothing more for a little, as if by such a speech something in\r\nhim were simplified and softened. \xe2\x80\x9cIt would be good for me--by which I\r\nmean it would be easier for me--if you didn\xe2\x80\x99t quite so immensely care\r\nfor him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d came from Nanda with an accent of attenuation at once so\r\nprecipitate and so vague that it only made her attitude at first rather\r\nawkward. \xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d she immediately repeated, but with an increase of the\r\nsame effect. After which, conscious, she made, as if to save herself, a\r\nquick addition. \xe2\x80\x9cDear Mr. Longdon, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it rather yourself most--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be easier for me,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, heedless, \xe2\x80\x9cif you didn\xe2\x80\x99t, my\r\npoor child, so wonderfully love him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh but I don\xe2\x80\x99t--please believe me when I assure you I DON\xe2\x80\x99T!\xe2\x80\x9d she broke\r\nout. It burst from her, flaring up, in a queer quaver that ended in\r\nsomething queerer still--in her abrupt collapse, on the spot, into the\r\nnearest chair, where she choked with a torrent of tears. Her buried face\r\ncould only after a moment give way to the flood, and she sobbed in a\r\npassion as sharp and brief as the flurry of a wild thing for an instant\r\nuncaged; her old friend meantime keeping his place in the silence broken\r\nby her sound and distantly--across the room--closing his eyes to his\r\nhelplessness and her shame. Thus they sat together while their trouble\r\nboth conjoined and divided them. She recovered herself, however, with an\r\neffort worthy of her fall and was on her feet again as she stammeringly\r\nspoke and angrily brushed at her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat difference in the world\r\ndoes it make--what difference ever?\xe2\x80\x9d Then clearly, even with the words,\r\nher checked tears suffered her to see how it made the difference that he\r\ntoo had been crying; so that \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know why you mind!\xe2\x80\x9d she thereupon\r\nwailed with extravagance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I would have done for him. You don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\r\nyou don\xe2\x80\x99t know!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated--while she looked as if she naturally\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t--as with a renewal of his dream of beneficence and of the\r\nsoreness of his personal wound.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but HE does you justice--he knows. So it shows, so it shows--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut in this direction too, unable to say what it showed, she had again\r\nbroken down and again could only hold herself and let her companion sit\r\nthere. \xe2\x80\x9cAh Nanda, Nanda!\xe2\x80\x9d he deeply murmured; and the depth of the pity\r\nwas, vainly and blindly, as the depth of a reproach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s I--it\xe2\x80\x99s I, therefore,\xe2\x80\x9d she said as if she must then so look at it\r\nwith him; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s I who am the horrible impossible and who have covered\r\neverything else with my own impossibility. For some different person you\r\nCOULD have done what you speak of, and for some different person you can\r\ndo it still.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stared at her with his barren sorrow. \xe2\x80\x9cA person different from him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA person different from ME!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what interest have I in any such person?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut your interest in me--you see well enough where THAT lands us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Longdon now got to his feet and somewhat stiffly remained; after\r\nwhich, for all answer, \xe2\x80\x9cYou say you WILL come then?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. Then\r\nas--seemingly with her last thought--she kept silent: \xe2\x80\x9cYou understand\r\nclearly, I take it, that this time it\xe2\x80\x99s never again to leave me--or to\r\nBE left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand,\xe2\x80\x9d she presently replied. \xe2\x80\x9cNever again. That,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\ncontinued, \xe2\x80\x9cis why I asked you for these days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, since you\xe2\x80\x99ve taken them--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh but have YOU?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nanda. They were close to each other now, and\r\nwith a tenderness of warning that was helped by their almost equal\r\nstature she laid her hand on his shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat I did more than\r\nanything else write to him for,\xe2\x80\x9d she had now regained her clearness\r\nenough to explain, \xe2\x80\x9cwas that--with whatever idea you had--you should see\r\nfor yourself how he could come and go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what good was that to do me? HADN\xe2\x80\x99T I seen for myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell--you\xe2\x80\x99ve seen once more. Here he was. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t care what he\r\nthought. Here I brought him. And his reasons remain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe kept her eyes on her companion\xe2\x80\x99s face, but his own now and\r\nafterwards seemed to wander far. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I care for his reasons so long\r\nas they\xe2\x80\x99re not mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe thought an instant, still holding him gently and as if for\r\nsuccessful argument. \xe2\x80\x9cBut perhaps you don\xe2\x80\x99t altogether understand them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why the devil, altogether, SHOULD I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh because you distinctly want to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nanda ever so kindly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nadmitted as much when we\xe2\x80\x99ve talked--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh but when HAVE we talked?\xe2\x80\x9d he sharply interrupted.\r\n\r\nThis time he had challenged her so straight that it was her own look\r\nthat strayed. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hesitated. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen HAVEN\xe2\x80\x99T we?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, YOU may have: if that\xe2\x80\x99s what you call talking--never saying a\r\nword. But I haven\xe2\x80\x99t. I\xe2\x80\x99ve only to do at any rate, in the way of reasons,\r\nwith my own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yours too then remain? You do know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTheir eyes, on that strange ground, could meet at last, and the effect\r\nof it was presently for Mr. Longdon. \xe2\x80\x9cI do know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d He raised his hands and took her face, which he drew so close to\r\nhis own that, as she gently let him, he could kiss her with solemnity\r\non the forehead. \xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d he then very firmly said--quite indeed as if it\r\nwere a question of their moving on the spot.\r\n\r\nIt literally made her smile, which, with a certain compunction, she\r\nimmediately corrected by doing for him in the pressure of her lips\r\nto his cheek what he had just done for herself. \xe2\x80\x9cTo-day?\xe2\x80\x9d she more\r\nseriously asked.\r\n\r\nHe looked at his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe paused, but clearly for assent. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I mean by your taking\r\nme as I am. It IS, you know, for a girl--extraordinary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh I know what it is!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed with an odd fatigue in his\r\ntenderness.\r\n\r\nBut she continued, with the shadow of her scruple, to explain. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nmany of us, we\xe2\x80\x99re most of us--as you long ago saw and showed you\r\nfelt--extraordinary now. We can\xe2\x80\x99t help it. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t really our fault.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s so much else that\xe2\x80\x99s extraordinary that if we\xe2\x80\x99re in it all so\r\nmuch we must naturally be.\xe2\x80\x9d It was all obviously clearer to her than\r\never yet, and her sense of it found renewed expression; so that she\r\nmight have been, as she wound up, a very much older person than her\r\nfriend. \xe2\x80\x9cEverything\xe2\x80\x99s different from what it used to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, everything,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned with an air of final indoctrination.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what he ought to have recognised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs YOU have?\xe2\x80\x9d Nanda was once more--and completely now--enthroned in\r\nhigh justice. \xe2\x80\x9cOh he\xe2\x80\x99s more old-fashioned than you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Longdon with a queer face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe tried,\xe2\x80\x9d the girl went on--\xe2\x80\x9che did his best. But he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t. And\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s so right--for himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer visitor, before meeting this, gathered in his hat and stick, which\r\nfor a minute occupied his attention. \xe2\x80\x9cHe ought to have married--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLittle Aggie? Yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nanda.\r\n\r\nThey had gained the door, where Mr. Longdon again met her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nthen Mitchy--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut she checked him with a quick gesture. \xe2\x80\x9cNo--not even then!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo again before he went they were for a minute confronted. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you\r\nanxious about Mitchy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe faltered, but at last brought it out. \xe2\x80\x9cYes. Do you see? There I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see. There we are.
